questions.prompt: Fix the sentence: Artificial Intelligence is widely used recently.
accepted: Artificial intelligence has been widely used recently.
Recently, artificial intelligence has been widely used.
questions.explanation: Use present perfect for a recent change with present relevance.
questions.grammarTitle: Present Perfect for Recent Past with Present Relevance
questions.detailedExplanation: When a situation began in the past and is still true now, prefer the present perfect: has been used, has increased. Simple present with ‘recently’ sounds unnatural.

questions.prompt: Fix the sentence: From my perspective this is a positive development because it give us the chance…
accepted: From my perspective, this is a positive development because it gives us the chance…
questions.topicNote: Match the verb to the head noun: it → gives; systems → give.
questions.detailedExplanation: Third-person singular subjects (it, AI, the system) take -s in the present simple: gives, helps, reduces.

questions.prompt: Fix the sentence: …the chance of spend our time on more meaningful activities.
accepted: …the chance to spend our time on more meaningful activities.
…the opportunity to spend our time on more meaningful activities.
questions.topicNote: Some nouns take an infinitive pattern: chance/opportunity/ability + to + V.
questions.detailedExplanation: After nouns like opportunity/ability/chance, use the to-infinitive (to spend), not a bare verb or ‘of + verb’.

questions.prompt: Choose the correct option: Many accidents are caused (by / for) driver distractions.
accepted: Many accidents are caused by driver distractions.
questions.topicNote: Cause + by indicates the agent/source of the effect.
questions.detailedExplanation: The preposition ‘by’ marks the agent in passive voice: was caused by; was built by.

questions.prompt: Fix the sentence: We trust more on AI’s capabilities to make complex tasks.
accepted: We trust more in AI’s capabilities to perform complex tasks.
We have greater trust in AI’s capabilities to perform complex tasks.
questions.detailedExplanation: With the abstract noun ‘trust’, use ‘in’: trust in technology. And prefer ‘perform/undertake’ rather than ‘make’ for tasks.

questions.prompt: Fix the sentence: We have the opportunity of use that time for building new ideas.
accepted: We have the opportunity to use that time to develop new ideas.
questions.topicNote: Noun + to-infinitive; use precise verb ‘develop ideas’.
questions.detailedExplanation: ‘Opportunity’ typically takes the to-infinitive. Replace vague ‘build ideas’ with ‘develop ideas’.

questions.prompt: Fix the sentence: the amount of accidents can be reduced.
accepted: The number of accidents can be reduced.
questions.explanation: Use ‘number of’ for countable plural nouns like ‘accidents’.
questions.detailedExplanation: Use ‘amount of’ with mass nouns (traffic, water) and ‘number of’ with countable plurals (accidents, reasons).

questions.prompt: Fix the sentence: a inmense ammount of CO2 is emmited to the world.
accepted: An immense amount of CO₂ is emitted into the atmosphere.
questions.explanation: ‘An’ before vowel sound; ‘CO₂ is emitted’; collocation ‘into the atmosphere’.
questions.detailedExplanation: Use ‘an’ before vowel sounds (immense). Prefer precise collocations: emitted into the atmosphere, not ‘to the world’.

questions.prompt: Correct the spelling: tourisim / accomodation / emmited
accepted: tourism; accommodation; emitted
questions.explanation: Common high-frequency spellings in IELTS topics.
questions.detailedExplanation: Memorise patterns: ‘accommodation’ has two c’s and two m’s; ‘emitted’ doubles the t.

questions.prompt: Correct the spelling: democratitation / ammount / consequencies
accepted: democratisation (UK) / democratization (US); amount; consequences
questions.topicNote: UK vs US variants both acceptable.
questions.detailedExplanation: Be consistent with UK spelling in IELTS Academic unless instructed otherwise.

questions.prompt: Fix the sentence: In Dublin exists a real problem with accommodation.
accepted: There is a real problem with accommodation in Dublin.
questions.explanation: Use the existential ‘there is’ structure in English.
questions.topicNote: Avoid direct transfer from languages that allow ‘exists’.
questions.detailedExplanation: English prefers ‘There is/are’ to introduce the existence of something.

questions.prompt: Improve the sentence: build new ideas and help to build a better society.
accepted: Develop new ideas and help build a better society.
questions.explanation: Use ‘develop ideas’; omit unnecessary ‘to’ after help.
questions.detailedExplanation: Prefer established academic collocations: develop ideas; foster innovation; help build (bare infinitive after ‘help’).

questions.prompt: Fix the sentence: increase on the personal carbon footprint.
accepted: increase in personal carbon footprint.
an increase in individuals’ carbon footprints.
questions.detailedExplanation: As nouns, ‘increase/decrease’ take ‘in’: an increase in prices; a decrease in emissions.

questions.prompt: Choose the correct word: International tourism brings (economic / economical) benefits.
accepted: International tourism brings economic benefits.
questions.explanation: ‘Economic’ relates to the economy; ‘economical’ means cheap/efficient.
questions.detailedExplanation: Use ‘economic growth/benefits/policy’; use ‘economical car/option’ for cost-efficiency.

questions.prompt: Fix the sentence: There are over priced accomodations for locals.
accepted: There is overpriced accommodation for locals.
Accommodation is overpriced for locals.
questions.explanation: ‘Accommodation’ is uncountable in UK English; write ‘overpriced accommodation’.
questions.detailedExplanation: Avoid pluralising mass nouns (*accommodations*) in UK academic English.

questions.prompt: Fix the sentence: Tesla cars nowadays is driven by AI.
accepted: Nowadays, Tesla cars are driven by AI.
questions.detailedExplanation: Be vigilant with plural nouns even when a brand name precedes them.

questions.prompt: Fix the sentence: impact of tourism on Earth is catastrophic.
accepted: The impact of tourism on the Earth is catastrophic.
Tourism’s impact on the Earth is catastrophic.
questions.explanation: Add the article with ‘Earth’ in this context; keep ‘impact on’.
questions.detailedExplanation: Use fixed prepositions: impact on, effect on, influence on.

questions.prompt: Fix the sentence: a new research by Oxford University shows tourism could produce almost the same amount of CO2 than the car industry.
accepted: New research from Oxford University shows that the tourism industry could produce almost the same amount of CO₂ as the car industry.
questions.explanation: Use ‘research’ uncountably; ‘from’ an institution; ‘as … as’ for comparison.
questions.detailedExplanation: Avoid ‘a research’; write ‘research’. For equal comparison, use ‘as + adjective/noun + as’.

questions.prompt: Fix the sentence: this accidents can be reduced if we use AI for drive cars.
accepted: These accidents can be reduced if we use AI to drive cars.
questions.explanation: ‘These’ with plural; use ‘to drive’ after ‘use AI to’.
questions.detailedExplanation: Use the to-infinitive to express purpose: use AI to drive, tools to reduce errors.

questions.prompt: Improve the sentence (concise, academic): Even though democratitation of tourism is a really good new for the pocket of the average Joe…
accepted: Although the democratisation of tourism is financially beneficial for many consumers…
questions.detailedExplanation: Replace colloquial phrases with neutral academic equivalents; correct uncountable ‘news’.

questions.prompt: Fix the sentence: local authorities allow that anyone run their own private hotel without asking for permition.
accepted: Local authorities allow anyone to run a private hotel without asking for permission.
questions.detailedExplanation: Correct structure: allow someone to do something, not ‘allow that someone do’.

questions.prompt: Fix the sentence: the have signifincantly reduced the amount of road accidents.
accepted: They have significantly reduced the number of road accidents.
questions.topicNote: Replace ‘amount of accidents’ with ‘number of accidents’.
questions.detailedExplanation: Use a clear subject pronoun and correct quantifier with plural countable nouns.

questions.prompt: Correct the spelling: relly / beens / environmnets / writting
accepted: really; beings; environments; writing
questions.topicNote: Double-t only in ‘written/writing’ → actually single ‘t’ in ‘writing’.
questions.detailedExplanation: Create flashcards with word + example sentence to reinforce correct forms.

questions.prompt: Fix the sentence: This accidents are increasing in the city centre.
accepted: These accidents are increasing in the city centre.
questions.detailedExplanation: Match demonstrative number to the noun: accidents → these.

questions.prompt: Fix the sentence: I don’t know what can we do to reduce emissions.
accepted: I don’t know what we can do to reduce emissions.
questions.explanation: In indirect questions, use statement word order.
questions.topicNote: No inversion after wh-word in indirect questions.
questions.detailedExplanation: Direct: ‘What can we do…?’ → Indirect: ‘…what we can do…’.

questions.prompt: Fix the run-on: As a society we trust more in AI’s capabilities for complex tasks, therefore now we have the opportunity to use that time to develop new ideas.
accepted: As a society, we trust more in AI’s capabilities for complex tasks; therefore, we now have the opportunity to use that time to develop new ideas.
As a society, we trust more in AI’s capabilities for complex tasks. Therefore, we now have the opportunity to use that time to develop new ideas.
questions.explanation: Separate independent clauses with a semicolon or full stop.
questions.topicNote: Avoid comma splices in formal writing.
questions.detailedExplanation: Use a semicolon, period, or coordinating conjunction to join independent clauses.

questions.prompt: Fix the sentence: International tourism has enormous benefit to many places.
accepted: International tourism has enormous benefits for many places.
International tourism brings enormous benefits to many places.
questions.explanation: Use plural ‘benefits’; ‘benefits for/to’ are both acceptable with slight nuance.
questions.topicNote: Abstract countable nouns often pluralise when generalising.
questions.detailedExplanation: When referring to multiple types of advantage, use ‘benefits’.

questions.prompt: Improve the sentence: But the truth is that this kind of tourism has a massive bad impact on local people.
accepted: However, this type of tourism has a substantial negative impact on local residents.
questions.explanation: Replace informal ‘But the truth is’ and vague ‘massive bad’ with precise academic wording.
questions.topicNote: Use ‘However’ to contrast and precise adjectives (substantial/negative).
questions.detailedExplanation: Academic tone avoids conversational fillers; choose specific evaluative language.

questions.prompt: Fix the sentence: In this cases, the family can afford the costs.
accepted: In these cases, the family can afford the costs.
In these cases the family can afford the costs
questions.grammarTitle: Demonstratives with Singular and Plural Nouns
questions.detailedExplanation: Use 'this' for singular nouns close in time/space and 'these' for plural nouns. Since 'cases' is plural, choose 'these'. Tip: say the noun first—if it’s plural, pick 'these'.

questions.prompt: Fix the sentence: The system can takes care of them.
accepted: The system can take care of them.
questions.explanation: Modals (can, could, may, might, must, should) take the base form.
questions.topicNote: After a modal, drop the -s/-ed: use the bare infinitive.
questions.detailedExplanation: Modal verbs are followed by the base form: can take, should consider, must pay. Do not add third-person -s or 'to'.

questions.prompt: Rewrite correctly: Many people cannot (access / access to) good education.
accepted: Many people cannot access good education.
Many people cannot access good-quality education.
Many people cannot access a good education.
questions.topicNote: Verb 'access' takes a direct object: access something.
questions.detailedExplanation: Some verbs are directly transitive (no preposition): access information, discuss a problem, approach a topic. Adding 'to' is a common error.

questions.prompt: Fix the sentence: The government should pay for that cares.
accepted: The government should pay for that care.
The government should pay for this care.
questions.topicNote: Uncountable nouns (care, advice, information) don’t take plural -s.
questions.detailedExplanation: Use 'care' (no -s) when referring to healthcare or assistance in general. Use quantifiers like 'some' or 'a lot of' if needed.

questions.prompt: Fix the sentence: They discovered that this students developed attention problems.
accepted: They discovered that these students developed attention problems.
questions.detailedExplanation: Demonstratives must agree in number with the noun they modify.

questions.prompt: Fix the sentence: Most accidents are caused for distractions.
accepted: Most accidents are caused by distractions.
questions.explanation: Use the collocation 'caused by', not 'caused for'.
questions.detailedExplanation: English uses fixed prepositions with certain verbs. Memorise 'caused by'.

questions.prompt: Fix the sentence: When it comes to go to school, children need a figure of authority.
accepted: When it comes to going to school, children need a figure of authority.
questions.explanation: After 'to' in a prepositional phrase, use the -ing form.
questions.detailedExplanation: In 'when it comes to + noun/gerund', 'to' is a preposition, so use 'going', not 'go'.

questions.prompt: Fix the phrase when used before a noun: in person teaching
accepted: in-person teaching
questions.explanation: Hyphenate compound modifiers before a noun.
questions.detailedExplanation: When two words act as one adjective before a noun, use a hyphen.

questions.prompt: Fix the phrase when used before a noun: face to face classes
accepted: face-to-face classes
questions.detailedExplanation: Write 'face-to-face' before a noun.

questions.prompt: Fix the phrase: many evidences
accepted: much evidence
a great deal of evidence
many pieces of evidence
questions.detailedExplanation: Prefer 'evidence' (no plural). If you need a countable form, use 'pieces of evidence'.

questions.prompt: Fix the sentence: They cannot afford pay for care.
accepted: They cannot afford to pay for care.
questions.topicNote: Common pattern: afford to do, agree to do, decide to do.
questions.detailedExplanation: Memorise high-frequency verbs that take the to-infinitive.

questions.prompt: Fix the sentence: It is well know that many children struggled during Covid.
accepted: It is well known that many children struggled during COVID-19.
It is well known that many children struggled during COVID.
questions.detailedExplanation: Use 'well known' after a verb; hyphenate 'well-known' before a noun.

questions.prompt: Fix the sentence: This proposition is far to be true.
accepted: This proposition is far from being true.
questions.explanation: The idiomatic phrase is 'far from being true'.
questions.detailedExplanation: Don't insert 'to' here; the pattern is 'far from being + adjective/noun'.

questions.prompt: Fix the acronym: MOC platforms (Coursera, EdX).
accepted: MOOC platforms (Coursera, EdX).
questions.explanation: The correct acronym is MOOC: Massive Open Online Course.
questions.detailedExplanation: Incorrect acronyms reduce clarity and credibility.

questions.prompt: Fix the phrase: reduce the amount of accidents
accepted: reduce the number of accidents
questions.explanation: Use 'number of' with countable nouns like 'accidents'.
questions.detailedExplanation: Choose 'number of' for countable items; 'amount of' for uncountable.

questions.prompt: Fix the sentence: The advantages of online courses is undeniable.
accepted: The advantages of online courses are undeniable.
questions.topicNote: Watch out for prepositional phrases that hide the plural subject.
questions.detailedExplanation: Ignore the prepositional phrase ('of online courses'); agree the verb with 'advantages'.

questions.prompt: Choose the correct form: A variety of platforms (offer / offers) free courses.
accepted: A variety of platforms offers free courses.
questions.topicNote: Identify the true head of the noun phrase.
questions.detailedExplanation: Although 'platforms' is plural, the head 'a variety' is singular, so use 'offers'.

questions.prompt: Fix the sentence: We have the opportunity of use that time for study.
accepted: We have the opportunity to use that time for study.
We have the opportunity to use that time to study.
questions.topicNote: Common pattern: opportunity to do something.
questions.detailedExplanation: Avoid 'of use' here; the natural construction is 'opportunity to use'.
